Thambiah3, , Soo Kun Lim4, Ahmad Zulkely5, Low Yoke Lee6, Nafisah Mohamad Noor5, Peck Ham Chuo5, Sazaliah Ishak5, Siti Sharina Anas7, Siti Suhana Abdullah Soheimi5, Raja Elina Raja Aziddin8 1Department of Pathology, Faculty of Medicine, University Malaya; 2Gleneagles Hospital Kuala Lumpur; 3Department of Pathology, Faculty of Medicine and Health Sciences, Universiti Putra Malaysia; 4Department of Medicine, Faculty of Medicine, University Malaya; 5Department of Pathology, Hospital Kuala Lumpur; 6Premier Integrated Labs, Kuala Lumpur; 7Department of Pathology, Hospital Putrajaya; 8Malaysian Association of Clinical Biochemists Abstract Chronic Kidney disease (chronic kidney disease) is a common clinical condition with significant health risks for patients and is widely recognised as a major public health concern. Laboratory medicine plays a crucial role in both diagnosing and managing chronic kidney disease, as diagnosis and staging rely on estimated glomerular estimated glomerular filtration rate (glomerular filtration rate) and evaluating albuminuria (or proteinuria). It was evident that the laboratory assessment of chronic kidney disease in Malaysia is not standardised. In light of this, the Malaysian Association of Clinical Biochemistry chronic kidney disease (MACB-chronic kidney disease) Task Force issued a national recommendation for laboratory diagnosis of chronic kidney disease in 2019. Recently, Kidney Disease: Improving Global Outcomes (Kidney Disease: Improving Global Outcomes) updated its recommendations for the diagnosis, evaluation, management, and treatment of chronic kidney disease. These guidelines incorporate the most recent evidence-based practices to support laboratory professionals in delivering optimal care for individuals with chronic kidney disease, focusing on critical areas such as estimated glomerular filtration rate (estimated glomerular filtration rate), albuminuria assessment, and risk stratification. The latest National Institute for Health and Care Excellence (NICE) guidelines on chronic kidney disease has also incorporated the Kidney Failure Risk Equation (KFRE) as a tool for predicting the likelihood of progression to end-stage Kidney disease (end-stage kidney disease) in chronic kidney disease patients. Hence, the MACB-chronic kidney disease Task Force has reviewed and updated its recommendations for laboratory reporting of estimated glomerular filtration rate and Urine albumin in alignment with the latest guidelines.
